comment.author: 8174133@N08
comment._content: It is interesting to see that Newtown had more platforms than it does today.

comment.author: 8793648@N06
comment._content: The northern/far platform was removed to make way for the 2 x fast intercity tracks in 1927 in conjunction with electrification. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newtown_railway_station,_Sydney

comment.author: 49503012504@N01
comment._content: There was also a special platform for funeral trains on the far left out of shot

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/indread_coal] That's interesting; I'm not sure if other other photos of Newtown station show this

comment.author: 49503012504@N01
comment._content: yes, the small white gabled building at the end of the last platform on the left: investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/indread_coal] Great, I'll put a larger version of this one up on Flickr on Friday. Thanks.

AB

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: that would be for tram funerals would it ?

comment.author: 49503012504@N01
comment._content: well, it was a regular stop for the TRAINS on the Necropolis line but it may have had direct access from the tram depot behind as well. I'm not aware of any tram funerals having taken place in Newtown, (apart from the transfer of remains from Devonshire St and the Old Burial Ground) but its concievable. The tram line down Church St to St Stephens was temporary though, it was single track and the hearse trailer was detached from the motor car at King St and hauled down the spur line by horse. 8 coffins per trailer I think, must have been slow work!
